articles.title: NOVEMBER 1985
articles.summary: This document outlines upcoming events for November and December 1985, including general meetings, field expeditions for astronomical observation, a board meeting, and an indoor star party. Key topics for general meetings include updates on the Hubble Space Telescope and discussions on active mirror telescopes. The schedule also notes a change for general meetings starting January 1986.

articles.title: BEATING MURPHY AT HIS OWN GAME BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: John Gleason details a challenging astrophotography session fraught with 'Murphy's Law,' including vehicle lights and strong winds from a nearby search operation. He effectively overcame these obstacles using his custom-built 'Blue Cube' astrophotography shelter, ensuring none of his exposures were ruined. The article also recounts observations of Comet Hartley/Good, Jupiter, and a surprisingly bright Comet Halley, alongside a successful test of Konica-ISO 1600 film in a cold camera for deep-sky imaging, with plans for further film and technique experimentation.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: At a star party, the author spent seven hours observing with Frank Dimoli's 90mm Celestron fluorite refractor, testing its limits on various celestial objects. They observed Jupiter at very high magnification, noting diffraction effects, and successfully detected challenging deep-sky objects like M8, M20, NGC 6822, and remarkably, Stefan's Quintet. The article emphasizes that the telescope's excellent performance was due to high light throughput and good baffling, rather than fluorite optics or specific eyepiece brands, suggesting similar results could be achieved with other well-maintained small refractors.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article details a well-attended ALCon meeting featuring Dr. Jack Marling of Lumicon, who presented stunning astrophotography from Mauna Kea. It describes Marling's specialized technique involving hypersensitizing Fujichrome 400 film, processing it as a negative, and then converting it back to a slide to achieve high contrast. The piece also discusses challenges with the 'new' Fuji film's blue sensitivity and introduces Konica ISO 1600 (Sakura of Japan) as a promising alternative for balanced deep-sky astrophotography.

articles.title: TED CARLSON TO SPEAK ON SPACE TELESCOPE
articles.summary: This document provides detailed instructions on handling hypered color negative film for astrophotography, covering topics such as C-41 processing, proper storage in a pressurized gas chamber to maintain sensitivity, and the effects of over-hypering on film grain. It differentiates between the storage longevity of hypered color and black & white films, concluding with the author's plan to test new un-hypersensitized film.

articles.title: AND YET ANOTHER COMET HALLEY TOUR
articles.summary: Explorer's Travel Club is offering a one-week tour to Australia, departing April 2nd from Los Angeles for $1050, which includes airfare, a Sydney tour, a chance to sight Comet Halley, and a meeting with Patrick Moore. An optional $450 extension to Alice Springs provides a rustic, camping-focused experience for further comet observation. The author notes that Bill Dellinger has signed up for the trip and reminds readers of a separate New Zealand tour.

articles.title: COMBINATION CHANGE
articles.summary: The padlock combination for the SJAA gate at the Grant Ranch upper site has been changed due to security concerns. Members wishing to use the site must now contact a board member and inform Grant Ranch park rangers prior to their visit to ensure proper access and avoid misunderstandings.

articles.title: ANOTHER MEDLOCK ROLLS OUT ONTO THE RAMP.
articles.summary: Kevin and Danni Medlock welcomed their baby boy, Paul Alan, on August 26th, after nearly ten months. Both parents are reported to be doing well following the birth.

articles.title: NEW COMET
articles.summary: The article announces the visibility of comet Hartley/Good in the northern sky early this month, expected to brighten to magnitude 5.5 by December, potentially outshining Halley for the rest of the year. It also details an upcoming presentation by Lockheed engineering manager, Ted Carlson, who will provide insights into the space telescope assembly operations in Sunnyvale, using slides as the telescope itself cannot be brought to the venue.

articles.title: ROYAL ALMANAC
articles.summary: SJAA members are offered a group discount on the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada's Observers Handbook for the 1986 observing season. Members interested in purchasing this informative paperback should contact Jim Van Nuland by December 1st to avail themselves of the offer.

articles.title: CALICO OBSERVATORY BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland reports on current observations of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), noting its pale but well-defined appearance despite excellent seeing conditions. He discusses the erratic nature of GRS transit timings and emphasizes the value of sketching for developing observing skills. The article encourages observers to take advantage of the current viewing window for Jupiter before it sets too early, providing a schedule of GRS meridian transits.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article reports on a surge in comet discoveries and recoveries in late 1985, making it an active year for comet observations. It details the recent findings of Comet Thiele, Comet Hartley-Good, and Comet Maury, providing their discovery dates, approximate magnitudes, and orbital information. Additionally, it notes Comet Halley's current position and its transition to an evening object by mid-month.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: The document provides ephemerides for Periodic Comet Giacobini-Zinner (1984e), covering dates from October 27 to December 6. It lists the comet's right ascension, declination, elongation from the Sun, and estimated visual magnitude, serving as a guide for observers to locate and track the comet.

articles.title: NOTES
articles.summary: This article provides observational notes on a comet, describing it as visually appealing from August to October despite producing few meteors in early October. It details the comet's distances from the Sun and Earth by the end of the month and predicts future viewing opportunities in six and thirteen years.

articles.title: COMET HARTLEY-GOOD (1985L)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Hartley-Good (1985L), detailing its predicted Right Ascension, Declination, Elongation, and estimated magnitude from late October to early December. It notes the comet will traverse the Milky Way and pass near the 1909 discovery location of Comet Halley. Observers can expect it to appear large and diffuse, with the listed magnitudes being rough estimates.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND--HALLEY'S
articles.summary: This article discusses the diminishing public 'hype' surrounding Halley's Comet as it begins to recede and become fainter, eventually requiring larger telescopes. It advises observers to utilize various instruments between now and next summer to make the most of its visibility. The author also explains the concept of integrated magnitude for extended objects like comets, noting they often appear less bright than a star of the same magnitude due to light spread and contrast issues, especially under light-polluted conditions.

articles.title: While we are on the subject, let me mention two more factors concerning comet magnitudes. First, a comet in a larger telescope, while appearing brighter than in a small scope, will not be enhanced as much as the gain in star visibility. That is, as aperture increases, the comet brightens but not as rapidly as the stars. A 10" telescope will yield a comet magnitude estimate about 0.4 magnitude fainter than what the standard aperture of 2.5" would yield. This is due to the nature of extended objects viewed by the eye. A second factor to remember is that photographic comet magnitude estimates are nearly always 1-4 magnitudes fainter than visual magnitudes.
articles.summary: This article explains two key factors influencing comet magnitude estimates: visual observations with larger telescopes yield proportionally fainter magnitudes for extended objects compared to stars, and photographic estimates are significantly fainter than visual ones. It also provides detailed November positional data for Halley's Comet, including its rapidly changing coordinates, magnitude, distance from Earth, opposition date, and visibility periods. The text further offers observational guidance, noting its path relative to other celestial objects and periods of lunar interference.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document, titled 'ASTRO ADS', features classified advertisements for astronomical equipment. Items for sale include a Meade 8-inch Newtonian telescope, an industrial 5mw Helium/Neon laser, and a tangent-arm assembly for guide scopes. There is also a 'wanted' ad for an equatorial mount and tripod for a C90, and an offering of telescope making equipment and services, including optical working and aluminizing.

articles.title: NEWS NOTZ: Late bulletin arrivals
articles.summary: Charles Carlson successfully observed Comet Halley from east San Jose with a 10-inch reflector, estimating its magnitude at 9.5. Access to the Loma Prieta observing site is now restricted by a locked gate, requiring a combination from Don Machholz. Additionally, public observing sessions for Comet Halley are scheduled at Branham Lane Park on multiple dates in November, December, and January, and volunteers are still encouraged to sign up.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article provides updates on U.S. space activities, detailing the successful completion of Space Shuttle Atlantis's classified mission 51-J and the upcoming launch of Challenger with the German Spacelab D-1 payload. It also describes the redesign of the U.S. Space Station to a "dual keel" configuration. Furthermore, it reports on the International Cometary Explorer (ICE) probe's flyby of Comet Giacobini-Zinner, which confirmed solar wind interaction theories and the dirty-snowball model of comets.

articles.title: COMET RENDEZVOUS MISSION KILLED
articles.summary: NASA has decided to cancel the proposed mission to rendezvous with comet Wild-2 and deploy a penetrator. Instead, the agency will prioritize funding for the International Solar-Terrestrial (ISTP) satellite program and the TOPEX oceanography spacecraft.

articles.title: SALYUT 7 HAS NEW CREW AND MODULE
articles.summary: A new three-man crew was launched to the Salyut 7 space station on Sept 17th, joining two existing cosmonauts in the first demonstration of overlapping crew operations before two returned to Earth. Shortly after, a large module was launched and docked, nearly doubling the station's size and adding a Gemini-sized reentry vehicle for returning goods.

articles.title: NEW SHUTTLE LAUNCH PAD BEING READIED
articles.summary: Pad 39B is currently being prepared for its first launch, Mission 51-L, scheduled for January 22nd. This launch pad is crucial for the planned Ulysses and Galileo missions set for May, which will occur just six days apart.

articles.title: CAUSE OF ARIANE FAILURE ATTRIBUTED TO VALVE
articles.summary: The Sept. 12th Ariane launch failure has been attributed to a faulty valve. A leakage in the third stage hydrogen injection valve, which is used to pre-cool the engine, is being blamed for the incident.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE IN AQUARIUS, PEGASUS, AND ANDROMEDA BY: JACK MARLING AND STEVE GOTTLIEB
articles.summary: This article discusses observing planetary nebulae in the constellations of Aquarius, Pegasus, and Andromeda, which are away from the galactic plane. It explains that planetary nebulae found in these regions tend to be relatively nearby, brighter, or larger in angular size. The authors highlight several specific examples, including large planetaries like NGC 7094 and NGC 7293, and bright showpieces such as NGC 7009 and NGC 7662.

articles.title: DESCRIPTION OF INDIVIDUAL OBJECTS
articles.summary: This article describes four individual planetary nebulae—NGC 7009, PEASE 1, NGC 7094, and IC 5148/50—providing details on their discovery, unique characteristics, and visual observing notes. It includes specific tips on filters, magnification, and challenges for amateur astronomers seeking to observe these deep-sky objects.

articles.title: DESCRIPTION OF INDIVIDUAL OBJECTS (continued)
articles.summary: The document is a continuation of a larger work focused on providing detailed descriptions of individual objects. It appears to be part of a catalog, report, or survey where specific characteristics and information about various entities are being documented systematically.

articles.title: NGC 7293
articles.summary: NGC 7293, also known as the "Helix Nebula," is a planetary nebula discovered by Curtis in 1918 with an integrated magnitude of 7.3. Despite its overall brightness, its large apparent size results in a low surface brightness, making it difficult to observe without filters. However, with O-III or UHC filters in larger telescopes, observers describe it as astounding, appearing as a bright, elongated disc with a darker center and often a distinct rim.

articles.title: Vy 2-3
articles.summary: Vy 2-3, a planetary nebula first identified by Milner in 1945, is a nearly stellar 13.6 magnitude object that requires a filter for observation. The author observed it on September 14, 1985, from Digger Pines, describing it as a "pretty bright 13th Stellar Planetary" using a 17½" telescope.

articles.title: NGC 7662
articles.summary: NGC 7662, discovered by William Herschel in 1784, is a bright 8th magnitude planetary nebula known for its double-shell structure. With high surface brightness, some observers can perceive its color, and it often presents an annular appearance with a darker center. Observations with a 13" telescope reveal a fainter outer shell encasing the main body.

articles.title: JONES 1
articles.summary: JONES 1 is a giant, exceedingly faint planetary nebula in Pegasus, discovered in 1941, with a very low surface brightness (15-16 magnitude). It is typically invisible without a filter but becomes a showpiece when observed with an O-III filter. The article includes a detailed visual observing report from 1984, describing it as a large, faint annular nebula with a dark center and an interior star, along with guidance for locating it.

articles.title: K 1-20
articles.summary: This article details the challenging observation of K 1-20, a 16th magnitude planetary nebula discovered by Kohoutek in 1963. The author, observing on August 25, 1985, described it as the faintest deep-sky object they had ever seen, requiring a 17½" telescope, O-III filter, averted vision, and full dark adaptation for a fleeting glimpse. It includes precise directions for locating the nebula.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE in AQUARIUS, PEGASUS, and ANDROMEDA
articles.summary: This document presents a detailed table of planetary nebulae located in the constellations of Aquarius, Pegasus, and Andromeda. For each nebula, it provides observational data including name, constellation, 2000.0 coordinates, size in arc-seconds, true visual magnitude, surface brightness (H magnitude), and the visual magnitude of its central star. The information is intended to aid in plotting and observing these objects, particularly the more obscure ones.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document outlines the details for monthly general meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" held by the SJAA at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. It provides the full address and detailed driving directions from Hwy. 17, noting that meetings commence at 8 PM.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is highlighted as a popular observing site for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), providing detailed directions via Mt. Hamilton Road and Alum Rock Road. The article includes crucial information about accessing the park after sunset, specifically mentioning a combination lock (4555) on the front gate and an additional observing area further up the road. It serves as a practical guide for members and visitors to the site.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Henry Coe State Park, including specific highway routes and landmarks like Anderson Reservoir. It details how to access a locked gate using a club combination (4555) and gives important instructions for night arrivals, such as parking outside and using parking lights only.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, specifically to Coulter Camp, which is a setup location for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines the route from Hwy 101 South, through Hwy 156 East, and then into the park, including a note about parking lights after dark. The document also mentions that it is published by the SJAA.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: The document lists the current officers of an organization, providing their titles, names, addresses, and phone numbers. Robert Fingerhut is listed as President, Dave Ambrose as Vice-President, James Van Nuland as Secretary, and Jack Peterson as Treasurer.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document lists the names and corresponding phone numbers of the individuals comprising the Board of Directors. It serves as a contact directory for the members of the board.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS EDITOR:
articles.summary: This document introduces John P. Gleason, providing his contact information including address and phone number, in relation to an 'Ephemeris Editor.' While details about the editor itself are not provided in this snippet, the document likely serves as an author credit or a point of contact for this specific tool or project.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), outlining different membership options and their costs, including standard, membership with Sky & Telescope magazine, and junior rates. It provides fields for applicant information and instructions for submission either at a meeting or by mail to the treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about members' astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise. It serves as a way for a non-profit organization, likely an astronomy club (SJAA), to understand its members' profiles and facilitate peer assistance. The document is labeled as 'NEWS MATERIAL' and indicates it's a 'TIME VALUE — DATED' publication.
